summary: Email correspondence from American Express Special Investigations Manager Kristina Hendrickson regarding a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) filed on Jeffrey Epstein's accounts. The email discusses providing the SAR and supporting documentation to a law enforcement contact, with instructions for secure access and legal use restrictions.

persons.name: Kristina Lee Hendrickson
persons.role: Manager - Special Investigations, Financial Intelligence Unit at American Express
persons.context: American Express employee who filed a SAR on Jeffrey Epstein's accounts and is coordinating with law enforcement to provide the documentation.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: Recipient of the email, addressed as 'Mr. Rossmiller', who previously discussed Epstein's account activity with Hendrickson and is requesting the SAR documentation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose American Express account activity prompted the filing of a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) by American Express.

connections.description: Correspondence regarding sharing financial investigation materials (SAR on Epstein) from American Express to law enforcement.
Hendrickson, as American Express Special Investigations Manager, filed a SAR on Epstein's account activity.
Law enforcement contact investigating Epstein's financial activity, based on previous discussions with American Express.

events.title: American Express files SAR on Epstein
events.description: American Express filed a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) regarding activity on Jeffrey Epstein's accounts.

events.title: Documentation transfer coordination
events.description: American Express coordinates secure transfer of SAR and supporting documentation to law enforcement.

locations: 18850 N. 56th Street, PHOENIX, AZ 85058 (American Express Financial Intelligence Unit office)
keyFacts: American Express filed a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) regarding Jeffrey Epstein's account activity.
The SAR and supporting documentation were being provided to law enforcement for investigative purposes in January 2020.
All documents were encrypted and required secure access procedures, indicating sensitive financial intelligence.
The correspondence emphasizes that the documents must be subpoenaed for use in court proceedings.
This shows ongoing financial investigation into Epstein's activities even after his death in 2019.
